author: mplomin
title: Mehen: Onboarding Assistance
description: There are high barriers to entry in the stable coin market for the unbanked/underbanked. Fiat-backed stable coins present a chicken & egg dilemma for creators in underdeveloped parts of the world.

f6_assessments.q0:
Currently, Cardano users will have to go to centralized exchanges like Binance, Coinbase, etc to buy ADA with other tokens like USDT, BUSD, BNB, etc and then transfer it back to their ADA wallet in Cardano. Doing this will take a lot of time and cost as well as risks that may affect the execution of transactions or loss of assets.
The Cardano network currently has an algorithmically backed stablecoin called Djed but it has to be minted through ADA so it is almost impossible to use it to increase the amount of ADA they want to hold.
Decentralized exchanges on Cardano are easy to conduct their transactions if the minted fiat-backed stablecoin is available on-chain. As such, on-chain stablecoins are a must for Cardano, the proposal is relevant for impact.
f6_assessments.q1:
Mehen's project team can accept this proposal. However, they have many proposals in FUND9 and using project milestone/timelines of another proposal for this proposal greatly reduces its feasibility.
Technically, they only mentioned that 1 USD will mint 1 MUSD but they have no idea how to mint it other than transferring the user's US dollars to US bank.
The biggest risk of minting fiat-backed stablecoins is making sure that the total value of the USD or locked assets is equal to the total value of stablecoins on the network is not mentioned. And don't see any solution to reduce this risk.
""This project is self-funding"" but haven't seen how it works, how it can be profitable and self-funded/operated has not been mentioned.
f6_assessments.q2:
The proposal only states that it costs 2USD per individual when KYC, total 5000 wallets are verified but does not give when it will be completed nor why it is only 5000 wallets.
Mehen only delivers the results they want when the project is completed.
The proposal does not provide corresponding project milestones and timelines, so it will be more difficult to audit.

f6_assessments.q0:
The concept of a fiat-backed stablecoin for Cardano is a good one, however this proposal only is about paying KYC incurred costs for people in underdeveloped parts of the world in order to access the services.
While this is generally a useful and good thing, I think the entire proposal could be a bit more descriptive, as a huge part of the impact saction is just copied from the main proposal and only small parts are explaining the actual purpose of this sub-prposal.
That being said, the proposal is only scalable with the amount of funds given into it and there would possibly be more efficient ways of performing more KYC checks on the same budget, e.G. by utilizing a crowd-operated method similar to the one applied in Pi-network.
f6_assessments.q1:
While the general framework of what is to be done is clear, plenty of points could still be described better: Which KYC provider will be utilized or if the KYC aplications will be self-performed, how will the process be designed?
How will people eligible for the free KYC be selected, on which criteria etc.? How will the timeline of the rollout be? What will be done once the funds are used, e.G. will there be some more free KYC opportunities financed by Mehen earnings?
Technical details are not really explained either. Some info on the team can however at least be found out when checking the website or the other proposal. That being said, at least a contingency plan has been made.
f6_assessments.q2:
The problem description is clear, however as mentioned above, some important details are missing in the description of the solution. A roadmap is missing, and while this seems like a very simple approach, for some of the missing planning mentioned above, one would still be in order.
Some metrics and success criteria are mentioned, some more quantifiable KPIs would however be in order.

f6_assessments.q0:
Personally I was a little confused with the title "Onboarding Assistance" and then I understand that this proposal is 1 of 3 proposals focusing to build a Stable Coin product for Cardano ecosystem. With explanation in the Impact section, Proposer and the company Mehen, seems are already prepared to develop this stable coin. In the cryptoverse, we can easily find articles about Tether which is not transparent in their USDT issue & redeem process. Proposer wrote that USDM or MUSD (need a concistency to write it) will issued and redeemed by Mehen company and will be backed by 1:1 $1 in an account at a US bank. That's the good things with this stable coin they plan to launch.
Proposer also already have a plan to get licences to run their USDM stable coin in their other proposal. One thing not mentioned in this proposal is "who will auditing the Stable Coin?" Once they get funding and launch their stable coin, it can be hard to audit when the majority are already using USDM in the DeFi ecosystem that will "generate new USDM from interest." It might be nice if Proposer can explain it too in the Risks section.
f6_assessments.q1:
In our local workshops, we are taught to assess every Proposal in a professional manner like there's no correlation do with any other proposals. Sadly, in this Feasibility section, Proposer only tell us to "go check our detailed plan in Mehen Licenses" or "go check our team in website." Yes We can check them that way. But I believe that is an unprofessional way to write a proposal. If this method is allowed, it means that everyone can fill out all parts of the proposal by simply "check our website for more details." Please take the time to write a good proposal according to the rules that have been determined.

So okay, I read the detailed plan and it's all well-writen and make sense to run it. The team are full of people with strong finance background. Their budget breakdown is a simple breakdown: $2 for KYC services cost and it allow 5,000 people to KYC. I think Proposer should explain where it ($2 KYC cost) come from too. Also, since this proposal is 1 of 3 Mehen's proposal, what if this proposal does not get a funding? So people should pay their KYC cost individually or else? This can be explain in the Risks part too.
f6_assessments.q2: Their metrics to measure who can literally measure is geographic regions where Mehen is being used, and the others (create future Cardano projects incubator) is can not be measured. Since it should be measured, I suggest the simple metrics could be a "how many USDM token issued," "how many people do a KYC process," or etc. To complete it, Proposer could provide those data too in their website, so Cardano community could publicly audit the metrics / KPIs.

f6_assessments.q0: The idea is very simple, but extremely necessary. It is about creating a stable coin minted on the Cardano blockchain, this is something that so far does not exist in our ecosystem, and in my view it can bring real profits to Cardano. Some activities need stable currencies, for example: a bidder is financed and receives monthly money from the IOG to pay his team's professionals, but if he receives a certain amount in Ada and it depreciates, how will he pay the full amount to his workers? Some of the proponents convert Ada to USDT, but this crypto is minted on Ethereum, so it would be very positive if a new currency was created – MUSD, as the proponent christened it, and that it was fully pegged to our technologies. In my view, the proposal deserves top marks for impact because it represents a solution that can make life easier for community members and drive Cardano adoption.
f6_assessments.q1: Unfortunately what the proposer does in the script part is not adequate. He asks us to consult other proposals to understand the action schedule, it would be necessary for the script to be posted here as well. We have no way of understanding how the two suggested parts would relate and how this would generate a single script to be followed. Ideally, he would explain, right here, what would happen each month, how, who would do it, etc. Talking about the budget, on the other hand, all that is said is that “KYC services cost approximately $2 per individual. This proposal will allow more than 5,000 people to receive KYC verified wallets.” These are not good explanations to justify the $10,000 asking price. No confidence is transmitted in the proponent either, as he does not attach any information about himself or about other people who would work on the project.
f6_assessments.q2: Auditability is 100% composed of partial results, in my view. The bidder did not include a number of necessary information, as I will enumerate. First, we don't know how the monitoring of the development process would be carried out – what would be done, when, how, by whom and why. No bridge is established with our community capable of positioning us on small advances. The success scenario is constructed in a somewhat generic way, it would be essential to have more details, to carry out a more in-depth research on the impacts of the creation of this stable currency. How did the idea achieve the goals of the challenge? For these reasons, I believe there is still a lot to be improved here.

f6_assessments.q0: The proposal aims to create a fiat(USD) backed Stablecoin  in Cardano Ecosystem similar to likes USDT, USDC etc. The idea is born out of the vision to provide a lower bar for inclusion of non-banked and underbanked people especially Africa with a reliable and cost efficient platform. However, the proposal is mainly a part of the whole project which is onboard users with a reliable KYC protocol. Overall,this is a laudable project that will definitely benefit the Cardano Ecosystem and its users and contribute to increased adoption of the Blockchain.
f6_assessments.q1: The proposal has explicitly elaborated on all it takes to bring this proposal to fruition that is the onboarding 5,000 users with verified wallets.The modalities were clearly explained with the acknowledgement of  relevant risk factors and possible solutions were proferred. From the information provided, the proponents has the requisite knowledge, skill and experience to deliver the project. The Budget Estimate was clear statement of relevant cost needed to achieve the purpose of the proposal. It is obvious that the proposal is one of many related proposal for the same project and having confirmed that a considerable amount of work has been done in bringing this idea to reality, am more than convinced that the team is more than capable to effectively implement this proposal.
f6_assessments.q2: The overall vision of this awesome proposal is crystal clear and it's benefits to the ecosystem and the world can not be overestimated. However bordering on this proposal, it is obvious that the only valid metric here is the onboarding process which is to get 5,000 verified wallets with ID/KYC. In addition, there was no specified timeline in the proposal to monitor the progress of this particular task but confirmed from other related proposals by the proponents however the existing website can serve as a credible means to assess and confirm the success of this proposal if eventually funded.

f6_assessments.q0: Stablecoin projects like the one Mehen are proposing will be vital to help maintaining and keeping value on the Cardano chain as the blockchain grows.  This project is building a collateralized stablecoin, but will require KYC/AML to be done as a requirement and could make the coin less desireable due to those facts.
f6_assessments.q1: As we have seen with algorithmic stablecoin collapses (although this isn't proposed to be an algorithmic stablecoin) getting a stablecoin that holds it's peg is extremely critical and requires a lot of capital to maintain the peg.  This project from a technical standpoint is likely possible, but from the financial and management perspective maybe a lot to ask of a team with this much experience and size.  A very high level of how it will be accomplished it listed, but there is no technical details, no mention of the team within the body of the proposal, and no mention of licensing agreements that have already been made to allow the use of the stablecoin in certain jurisdictions.
f6_assessments.q2: The metrics and KPIs listed do not really allow for tracking of how the project will be executed, managed, and/or tracked and doesn't give confidence in it's transparency and auditability.

solution: Mehen wishes to lower the barrier to entry unbanked creators and investors face by subsidizing the cost required to enter the Mehen ecosystem, including background check and ID verification expenses.
experience: Matthew Plomin, Founder of Mehen, has been involved in fiduciary TradFi for nearly fifteen years, managing US credit research for liquidity products. He has navigated multiple regulatory reforms in the US and European money market industries.
